p: One of the first strategies to prevent diseases was to cause a mild primary infection with the original pathogen that would cure spontaneously and would provide protection against the full disease in the future ( 2). In the case of smallpox, however, this process, called variolation, caused the disease itself in 3% of the vaccinated individuals. Live vaccines were also used against Leishmania infections in the former URSS and Middle East ( 3). However, this practice was discontinued because of the recent increase in the population of immunocompromised subjects, in which live or attenuated vaccines could revert to virulence.
